t: Job 33
Elihu Rebukes Job
“But*pn now, hear my speech, O Job, and*ld listen to all my words.
Behold,*ln I open my mouth; the*ld tongue in my mouth speaks.
My*ln words declare the uprightness of my heart, and*ld what my lips know they speak sincerely.
The*ln Spirit of God has made me, and*ld the breath of the Almighty gives me life.
Answer*ln me, if you can; set*ld your words in order before me; take your stand.
Behold,*ln I am toward God as you are; I*ld too was pinched off from a piece of clay.
Behold,*ln no fear of me need terrify you; my*ld pressure will not be heavy upon you.
“Surely*pn you have spoken in my ears, and*ld I have heard the sound of your words.
You*ln say, ‘I am pure, without transgression; I*ld am clean, and there is no iniquity in me.
Behold,*ln he finds occasions against me, he*ld counts me as his enemy,
he*ln puts my feet in the stocks and*ld watches all my paths.’
“Behold,*pn in this you are not right. I will answer you, for*ld God is greater than man.
Why*ln do you contend against him, saying,*ld ‘He will answer none of man’s words’?
For*ln God speaks in one way, and*ld in two, though man does not perceive it.
In*ln a dream, in a vision of the night, when*ld deep sleep falls on men, while*ld they slumber on their beds,
then*ln he opens the ears of men and*ld terrifies them with warnings,
that*ln he may turn man aside from his deed and*ld conceal pride from a man;
he*ln keeps back his soul from the pit, his*ld life from perishing by the sword.
“Man*pn is also rebuked with pain on his bed and*ld with continual strife in his bones,
so*ln that his life loathes bread, and*ld his appetite the choicest food.
His*ln flesh is so wasted away that it cannot be seen, and*ld his bones that were not seen stick out.
His*ln soul draws near the pit, and*ld his life to those who bring death.
If*ln there be for him an angel, a*ld mediator, one of the thousand, to*ld declare to man what is right for him,
and*ln he is merciful to him, and says, ‘Deliver*ld him from going down into the pit; I*ld have found a ransom;
let*ln his flesh become fresh with youth; let*ld him return to the days of his youthful vigor’;
then*ln man prays to God, and he accepts him; he*ld sees his face with a shout of joy, and*ln he restores to man his righteousness.
He*ld sings before men and says: ‘I*ln sinned and perverted what was right, and*ld it was not repaid to me.
He*ln has redeemed my soul from going down into the pit, and*ld my life shall look upon the light.’
“Behold,*pn God does all these things, twice,*ld three times, with a man,
to*ln bring back his soul from the pit, that*ld he may be lighted with the light of life.
Pay*ln attention, O Job, listen to me; be*ld silent, and I will speak.
If*ln you have any words, answer me; speak,*ld for I desire to justify you.
If*ln not, listen to me; be*ld silent, and I will teach you wisdom.”
